subject: Re: [junit] command line option to suppress output results thrown on screen by junit?
msgSnippet: Thanks David. I have already tried the first option. But that requires me to click manually to let the jprobe continue execution. So I guess I will have to
messageBody:
Thanks David.
I have already tried the first option. But that
requires me to click manually to let the jprobe
continue execution. So I guess I will have to give a
shot at the second option.

- Suganya

--- David Saff <saff@...> wrote:

> Suganya,
>
> There isn't a command-line option for that. You
> could try:
>
> 1) Using junit.swingui.TestRunner, which doesn't
> print to the console,
> but does pop up a window.
> 2) Writing your own TestRunner, inspired by looking
> at the source of
> junit.textui.TestRunner
>
> Good luck,
>
> David Saff
>
> suganya s wrote:
>
> > Hi,
> >
> > The software that I am trying to test for coverage
> is
> > not an application program... that is it is based
> > servlets and the like and hence does not have a
> main
> > method. But If i have to test for the coverage
> using
> > jprobe , i need to mention the application's name
> as
> > an argument for the coverage task of junit.
> >
> > To solve this problem, I made a TestSuite called
> > AllTests.java and added in all the suites.
> > For the name of the application, I passed
> > junit.textui.TestRunner and I passed AllTests as
> its
> > argument.
> >
> > But when I try running the coverage task,
> > jplauncher.exe after all my tests execute because
> of
> > the failures and errors thrown on the output
> screen by
> > junit. Is there a command line option to suppress
> > junit from printing on the command line?
> >
> > Thanks,
> > Suganya Subramanian
> >
> > __________________________________________________
> > Do You Yahoo!?
> > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam
> protection around
> > http://mail.yahoo.com
> >
> >
>
